headline: Toronto woman with restraining order says police were 'too busy' to help when she tried to report a breach | CBC News
context: Toronto woman says police were ‘too busy’ to enforce restraining order against ex-boyfriend
For Seojin Kim, going to the courts to get a restraining order felt like the only option after she broke up with her former partner.

annotations.paragraph: Despite asking him to stop contacting her and blocking him, she says the calls, emails and texts were relentless — 450 missed calls, 11 voicemails and 500 emails in roughly six weeks. When she blocked his numbers, she says he'd call from a different line, and when she blocked his email, he created alternate addresses.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the harassment Kim faced, which is relevant to the story.

annotations.paragraph: She says he loitered outside her home and work waiting for her, and even showed up at her workplace once, "pretending to be a customer."
annotations.reason: This paragraph adds context to the severity of the situation and the ex-boyfriend's behavior.

annotations.paragraph: "I was feeling unsafe and kind of scared about every time I had to go outside," Kim told CBC Toronto.
annotations.reason: This quote provides insight into Kim's emotional state, which is relevant to the story.

annotations.paragraph: But even after an Ontario Superior Court Justice granted the 28-year-old a protective order on Feb. 21, 2025 that barred her ex from contacting her or being within 500 metres of her home or work, she says it was a struggle to get Toronto police to enforce it.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is crucial as it highlights the main issue of police inaction despite the protective order.

annotations.paragraph: Her ex allegedly breached the order, reaching out to a friend of hers to make contact, then once again emailing her and sending her multiple e-transfers so that he could attach a message. CBC Toronto has reviewed dozens of these emails and messages.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides evidence of the breach and supports the main premise of the article.

annotations.paragraph: When she first brought the protective order and extensive evidence of the breaches to Toronto police's 51 Division on April 12, she said no officer would even look at it — with one telling her, "we are too busy right now."
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the incident and the police response.

annotations.paragraph: While her ex was eventually arrested, Kim says she doesn't understand why it took repeated attempts to enforce her restraining order.
annotations.reason: This paragraph adds information about the eventual arrest and Kim's confusion over the process.

annotations.paragraph: "It doesn't make sense, they have to protect me; it's their duty. That's why we got a restraining order," said Kim. "If they don't do anything, then what's the point of a restraining order?"
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a direct quote from Kim expressing her frustration and questioning the effectiveness of the restraining order.

annotations.paragraph: Kim, a Korean immigrant who moved to Toronto in 2023, says she felt dismissed after the initial visit.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about Kim's background and her feelings after the police visit.

annotations.paragraph: "They told me I had two options: sit and wait for several hours – with no guarantee I'd actually get to speak – or call the non-emergency line," Kim said.
annotations.reason: This paragraph details the options given to Kim by the police, contributing to the narrative.

annotations.paragraph: In 2023, the Law Commission of Ontario, an independent group that looks at legal reform, began a project reviewing protective orders in the province – including how they're enforced – following the recommendation of the Barbra Schlifer clinic.

annotations.paragraph: "When police are not effectively enforcing protection orders, it actually means that abusers are more empowered to keep breaching those orders," said Laura Snowdon, the lawyer leading the commission's review.

annotations.paragraph: Not only do women have to jump through significant procedural and evidentiary hurdles to even get a protection order, Snowdon says, but in cases where they are granted one, the rates of non-compliance are extremely high.
